Hi Ron, a nice observation. and possibly correct. I went right through 
the Akasaka books and cannot find a single tsuba with the kakushi-tagane 
though straight lines were used form time to time by the second 
Tadamasa. Akasaka and Tosa Myochin can at times be very hard to separate 
I find but it is these little tips that help separate them that make the 
job just a tad easier.

I guess one thing is, when in hand, it's look of age might help. Sasano 
reports that the Tosa Myochin group started in the mid 1800's or there 
abouts. I have a signed Tosa Myochin tsuba signed Toshu ju Kuniyoshi 
Saku ( shoshin according to Hagihara sensei ) that would date to about 
1780 - 1800. I know Cary has a Tosa Myochin piece about the same age. I 
have not heard of them earlier than that, has anyone else ?. I kind of 
think from the images, this tsuba of mine looks older than the 1800's, 
but then again, as I a said, when I have it in hand, it may be easier to 
tell.

Anyway, food for thought, I like Tosa Myochin also as a school and would 
not be upset if it turned out that way.

best wishes

Rich


Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Hi Rich, all -
>
> Not to be a wet blanket here but--referring to the first tsuba with 
> chidori--I suspect this would be designated Tosa Myochin made in 
> Akasaka style. I say this because of the distinctive tagane 
> (kakushi-tagane) around the nakago-ana, a Tosa Myochin trait according 
> the Sasano and others. (Sasano points this out in his original English 
> sukashi tsuba book, pages 218-220.)
>
> Not to muddy up the waters, but an odd experience with a like-tsuba 
> was experienced by me back in the early 1980s. In 1979 during a 
> Chicago NTHK shinsa, Sasano papered a friend's mumei tsuba as (I 
> believe) 2nd master Akasaka work. Later, the tsuba went to a Haynes 
> auction where I purchased it. Bob Haynes was adamant about the tsuba 
> "looking like" Akasaka, but that in reality it was Tosa Myochi. His 
> argument was based largely on these "wisker-like" kakushi-tagane that 
> were place around the tsuba's nakago-ana. I sold that tsuba a year or 
> two ago and passed on this story along with the original NTHK paper 
> declaring it Akasaka. Either way, it remains a fine tsuba!
>
> Ron
> STL
